articles.author: Kalana Heshan
articles.description:
Your app icon is often the first impression users have of your mobile application. In a crowded app store where millions of apps compete for attention, a well-designed icon can be the difference between a download and a scroll-past. It's not just a small graphic ‚Äì it's your brand's ambassador, marketing tool, and the visual gateway to your app's experience.
Think about the icons on your phone right now. Instagram's camera gradient, Spotify's green waves, or WhatsApp's speech bubble ‚Äì these aren't just random designs. They're carefully crafted visual statements that communicate function, personality, and quality in a space smaller than your thumbnail.
In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore the art and science of creating mobile app icons that not only look stunning but also drive downlo‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to Design a Mobile App Icon: Best Practices for Success

Os centros de apoio √† resili√™ncia desempenham um papel fundamental nesse cen√°rio, funcionando como pontos estrat√©gicos para coordena√ß√£o, assist√™ncia e recupera√ß√£o. A disponibilidade de ilumina√ß√£o adequada assegura que equipes de socorro, volunt√°rios e moradores possam atuar com efic√°cia, minimizando riscos e facilitando opera√ß√µes de evacua√ß√£o ou manuten√ß√£o. articles.author: Franck
articles.description:
This morning I stumbled upon bolt.new hackathon and thought it would be interesting to participate to see how far AI can take an idea to a fully functioning application and perhaps I will learn a few things along the way.
I am used to AI in programming, using Github Copilot everyday, but never really used an AI online editor such as bolt.new for something bigger than a landing page or a simple mini-game. I guess it's time to give it a go!
First step is to register here, then you have to wait for the Builder Pack, which includes a free Bolt.new Pro subscription and other goodies. Given that more than 60k participants have registered it might take some time!
While waiting for receiving the email, it's time to brainstorm and plan.
This is going to be fun, more on that tomorrow when I (hopefully) receive the builder pack and register the domain name.
While I am proficient using React and Nextjs, I see this hackathon as an opportunity to try something new. I want to give building mobile applications a go and/or learn a new framework.
I hesitated between Nuxt + Capacitor and Expo to build a cross platform app easily and decided to go the Expo route.
For the backend I'm going to use something new too, Appwrite! I am familiar with Supabase, Convex, and Firebase but never given that one a shot, it looks promising.
That's it for today, see you tomorrow for day 2 üöÄ
articles.title: üöÄ Bolt.new hackathon - Here we go!

Quando inc√™ndios ocorrem, a libera√ß√£o de fuma√ßa pode se transformar numa amea√ßa silenciosa, invis√≠vel e altamente t√≥xica, dificultando a evacua√ß√£o e comprometendo a sa√∫de das pessoas presentes. Essa abordagem prioriza √°reas de maior perigo ou vulnerabilidade, garantindo que a atua√ß√£o seja mais r√°pida e eficiente na conten√ß√£o e na retirada de fuma√ßa prejudicial. Dessa forma, o monitoramento, a automa√ß√£o e o planejamen‚Ä¶

articles.author: Sourav Yadav
articles.description:
Hey folks üëã
Welcome back to Day 02 of my ‚ÄúEscape Tutorial Hell‚Äù dev journey!
Today was all about organizing my code, getting better with version control, and discovering how powerful browser DevTools can be.
Added a new blog post page: day02.html

Created an external CSS file (assets/style.css) to clean up inline styles
Styled my navigation bar using basic CSS ‚Äî looks much cleaner now!
Learned how to use git merge to combine my stylize branch into main

Spent time exploring DevTools (box model, layout debugging, color picker)
I‚Äôve heard from one awesome dev about using Svelte for templating HTML components like navbars. Sounds cool, but I‚Äôm yet to figure it out. If you‚Äôve got some resources or advice, please share!
Using Git branches is like time-travel for code ‚Äî git merge helped me combine styling changes smoothly.

DevTools is a game-changer! I now understand how layout and spacing actually work ‚Äî not just in theory.
Improve the design of the site with a minimal theme
Explore templating options like Svelte or maybe try out something else
Keep building, learning, and documenting here and soon get to the point of implementing MERN stack or Next.JS
üí¨ Your feedback means a lot!
If you‚Äôre a fellow dev, beginner or experienced ‚Äî I‚Äôd love your thoughts on:
Minimal design suggestions (colors, fonts, spacing)
HTML templating tools you recommend
How you tackled layout issues early in your journey
Let's build and grow together! üå±
üñ•Ô∏è Live Blog: https://codingtheself.github.io/webdevblog
Until tomorrow,
Sourav Yadav
articles.title: Day 02 - Making My Blog More Modular with CSS & Learning Git Merge

articles.author: Mohd Anas
articles.description:
Look, there's a real joy in coding. Spending hours on it, racking your brain, and then seeing that program finally run perfectly ‚Äì it's a feeling like no other! I learned the same way. I did everything myself from A to Z, without any AI tools. Figuring out logic, squashing bugs on my own, even late at night ‚Äì I've been through all of it. So yes, I can absolutely write code without AI, easily.
But, to be honest, I wouldn't want to code without AI now.
And it's not because I don't want to work hard or I've become lazy. Not at all! This is just about working smart. Think about it: if you have a bike, would you walk a long distance just because you know how to walk? It would feel a bit strange, right? AI tools are something like that.
The very first thing ‚Äì speed, my friend! It saves so much t‚Ä¶
articles.title: I know how to code without ai, but I wouldn't

articles.author: Vaibhav Kulshrestha
articles.description:
Let‚Äôs dive into how software testing is transforming and what QA professionals must prioritize this year:
In the age of CI/CD, fast releases are the norm. This demands:
Instant feedback loops
Seamless integration of testing in pipelines
Zero bottlenecks for manual approvals
Teams must embrace test orchestration tools, automated pipelines, and shift-left strategies to keep pace.
AI is now an enabler of smarter testing ‚Äî not a threat to testers. It powers:
Automated test case generation
Anomaly detection in test data
Predictive defect analysis
However, human expertise is still essential for validating AI outputs and handling edge cases.
While automation handles repetition, exploratory testing brings creativity, intuition, and experience into play. It‚Äôs especially powerful for:
UX validation
Identifying gaps automation misses
Testing real-world user flows
Exploratory testing bridges the gap between scripts and user empathy.
With rising data regulations (like GDPR, HIPAA), security testing is mandatory ‚Äî from static code analysis to penetration testing.
Likewise, accessibility testing ensures inclusive design:
Use WCAG guidelines
Test with screen readers
Validate color contrast, keyboard navigation, etc.
Accessible software = better UX + legal compliance.
Great testing fails without realistic, privacy-compliant test data. Teams must:
Mask sensitive info
Generate synthetic data for edge cases
Manage data sets for repeatability
Test data is no longer a backend concern ‚Äî it‚Äôs part of test strategy.
Software testing in 2025 is less about "testing more" and more about "testing smarter." That means:
Cross-functional collaboration
Data-informed prioritization
Embracing change and lifelong learning
Testers today are quality advocates, not just bug finders.
Let‚Äôs connect and share insights!
articles.title: üîç Software Testing in 2025: Adapting to a Fast-Changing Digital Landscape

articles.author: Ujjwal Raj
articles.description:
Welcome to another Sunday article where we dive into system design.
As I already stated: we are going to learn the rules, follow the rules, and once you are an expert ‚Äî bend the rules.
A good system design speaks (how components interact)
Avoid functional decomposition (what we were doing in universities)
The client should not be the core business. Let the client be the client ‚Äî not the system
Reduce coupling between services as much as possible
I‚Äôll be adding more to this list as we proceed in the series.
It is very difficult to convince engineers to avoid functional decomposition, since it is the easiest and most straightforward approach. But by the end of this series, I assure you ‚Äî the readers will be convinced, just as Juval convinced me through his book.
In software companies, when t‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Anti-Design Thinking in System Design

Com o avan√ßo tecnol√≥gico, solu√ß√µes inovadoras t√™m surgido para identificar rapidamente diferentes tipos de gases presentes no ar, permitindo uma resposta eficiente a situa√ß√µes de perigo. Al√©m disso, a implementa√ß√£o de sistemas automatizados de controle de fuma√ßa baseado nesses sensores aumenta a efici√™ncia na comunica√ß√£o de alertas ‚Ä¶

articles.author: Mohd Anas
articles.description:
Remember when coding felt like a job? All those tough rules, strange errors, and long hours fixing things. Well, those days are fading fast, thanks to something many are calling "vibe coding." It's not just about making coding easier; it's about making it truly enjoyable, almost like playing a game.
It might sound odd to be hooked on a simple text screen for building things, but it's true. Lots of people are spending their free time using tools like Cursor, v0, and their favorite AI chat friends (like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini) to bring their ideas to life. And it's not just for people who code for a living; designers, product managers, business starters, and marketers are all trying it.
So, what's the big secret? It feels like coding as a game. And we're not talking about just getting p‚Ä¶
articles.title: Vibe Coding: Making Building Fun Again
